```{ojs}
dataScript = FileAttachment("../data/db/data.json").json()


materialsById = new Map(dataScript.materials.map(m => [m.id, m]))
unitsById = new Map(dataScript.units.map(u => [u.id, u]))
planetsById = new Map(dataScript.planets.map(p => [p.id, p]))

// Function to get component materials
function getComponentMaterials(componentId) {
  return dataScript.unitMaterials
    .filter(um => um.unit_id === componentId)
    .map(um => {
      const material = materialsById.get(um.material_id);
      return {
        symbol: material?.symbol,
        name: material?.name || um.material_id,
        fraction_pct: um.fraction_pct,
        isLocal: mercuryMaterials.has(um.material_id)
      };
    });
}

// Function to display unit widget
function unitWidget(unitId) {
  const unit = unitsById.get(unitId);
  if (!unit) return html`<div class="db-widget">Unit ${unitId} not found</div>`;

  const planet = planetsById.get(unit.production_planet_id);

  // Base unit materials
  const materials = dataScript.unitMaterials
    .filter(um => um.unit_id === unitId)
    .map(um => {
      const material = materialsById.get(um.material_id);
      const isLocal = mercuryMaterials.has(um.material_id);
      const massKg = unit.mass_kg ? (unit.mass_kg * um.fraction_pct / 100).toFixed(0) : null;
      return { ...um, material, isLocal, massKg };
    });

  // Components (subassemblies)
  const components = dataScript.unitComponents
    .filter(uc => uc.assembly_id === unitId)
    .map(uc => {
      const component = unitsById.get(uc.component_id);
      const totalMassKg = component?.mass_kg ? (component.mass_kg * uc.quantity) : null;
      const isLocal = component?.production_planet_id === unit.production_planet_id;
      const componentMaterials = getComponentMaterials(uc.component_id);

      return {
        id: uc.component_id,
        name: component?.name || uc.component_id,
        quantity: uc.quantity,
        massKg: totalMassKg,
        isLocal,
        materials: componentMaterials
      };
    });

  // Total calculated ONLY from materials (not components!)
  const localPct = materials.filter(m => m.isLocal).reduce((sum, m) => sum + m.fraction_pct, 0);
  const importPct = materials.filter(m => !m.isLocal).reduce((sum, m) => sum + m.fraction_pct, 0);
  const hasCriticalImports = components.some(c => !c.isLocal);

  // Component table rows
  const componentRows = components.map(c => html`
    <tr class="component-row">
      <td>
        <strong>${c.name}</strong>${c.quantity > 1 ? html` x${c.quantity}` : ''}
        <div class="component-materials">
          ${c.materials.map(m => html`<span class="${m.isLocal ? 'local' : 'import'}">${m.symbol || m.name} ${m.fraction_pct}%</span>`)}
        </div>
      </td>
      <td>${c.massKg ? c.massKg.toFixed(0) : '—'} kg</td>
      <td class="${c.isLocal ? 'local' : 'import'}">${c.isLocal ? '✓' : '⚠ import'}</td>
    </tr>
  `);

  // Material table rows
  const materialRows = materials.map(m => html`
    <tr>
      <td>
        ${m.material?.symbol ? html`<strong>${m.material.symbol}</strong> ` : ''}
        ${m.material?.name || m.material_id}
      </td>
      <td>${m.fraction_pct}%</td>
      <td>${m.massKg || '—'} kg</td>
      <td class="${m.isLocal ? 'local' : 'import'}">${m.isLocal ? '✓ local' : '⚠ import'}</td>
    </tr>
  `);

  return html`
    <div class="db-widget">
      <h4>${unit.name} <span style="color: #6c757d; font-weight: normal;">(${unit.id})</span></h4>
      <div class="meta">
        ${unit.mass_kg ? html`<strong>${unit.mass_kg.toLocaleString()}</strong> kg` : ''}
        ${unit.power_kw ? html` | <strong>${unit.power_kw.toLocaleString()}</strong> kW` : ''}
        ${planet ? html` | Production: ${planet.name}` : ''}
      </div>

      ${components.length > 0 ? html`
        <div class="section-header">Components</div>
        <table class="components-table">
          <thead><tr><th>Component</th><th>Mass</th><th>Source</th></tr></thead>
          <tbody>${componentRows}</tbody>
        </table>
      ` : ''}

      ${materials.length > 0 ? html`
        <div class="section-header">Materials</div>
        <table class="materials-table">
          <thead><tr><th>Material</th><th>%</th><th>Mass</th><th>Source</th></tr></thead>
          <tbody>${materialRows}</tbody>
        </table>
        <div class="summary">
          Total: <span class="local-pct">${localPct.toFixed(0)}% local</span> |
          <span class="import-pct">${importPct.toFixed(0)}% import</span>
          ${hasCriticalImports ? html`<br/><strong>⚠ Contains imported components</strong>` : ''}
        </div>
      ` : ''}

      <div class="link">
        <a href="data/nomenclature.html?unit=${unitId}">Details →</a>
      </div>
    </div>
  `;
}
```

> **TL;DR**
>
> Mercury's energy system consists of two independent subsystems:
>
> **Section 1: Energy for Production**
> - **Solar Boost:** 9-14 kW/m² (vs 1.3 kW/m² on Earth)
> - **Power Towers:** GaAs cells with NaK cooling
> - **Cryo-Transmission Lines:** Aluminum at -150°C — resistance 10x lower
> - **Silicon Panels:** Aluminothermic process (100% local production)
>
> **Section 2: Energy for Mass Drivers**
> - **Peak Power:** 400 MW during launch
> - **Average Power:** 33 MW per Mass Driver (600 launches/day)
> - **Capacitors:** Energy storage between launches
> - **Cooling:** ~20 MW heat via NaK + radiators

---

## Energy System Overview

Mercury's energy infrastructure addresses two fundamentally different challenges:

1. **Continuous power supply for production** — factories, furnaces, conveyors (50-55 MW per complex)
2. **Pulsed power for Mass Drivers** — peak loads 400 MW, average 33 MW

The systems are separated because they have different operating modes and requirements.

---

# Section 1: Energy for Production

*Generation. Without this stage, the factory is just a pile of metal.*

## Mercury Physics (Solar Boost)

| Location | Solar Flux |
| :--- | :--- |
| Earth Orbit | 1.3 kW/m² |
| Mercury | 9–14 kW/m² |

Mercury receives **7-11 times** more solar energy than Earth. This is a fundamental advantage for solar power generation.

---

## Concentrator Mirrors

All mirrors for the first factory are delivered from Earth in folded form.

| Parameter | Value |
| :--- | :--- |
| Material | Ultra-light polymer film (Kapton) with aluminum coating |
| Weight | 50 g/m² |
| Total kit weight | < 1 ton |
| Design | Deploy on carbon fiber spokes (like umbrellas) |
| Purpose | Power generation (on towers) + metal smelting (in furnaces) |

---

## Power Towers

Installed by climbing robots on "Peaks of Eternal Light" (crater rims).

**Principle:** Mirrors focus light on photovoltaic cells.

**Photovoltaic Cells:**
- Type: Multi-junction gallium arsenide (GaAs)
- Properties: Expensive but durable

**Cooling (radiative):**
- No convection in vacuum
- Cannot use ground (insulator)
- Liquid NaK circulates inside the mast, absorbing heat from the hot cells
- Liquid flows to the shadowed side of the tower to a radiator
- Radiator "shines" toward cold space (3K) or the dark crater floor (-150°C), dissipating heat through radiation

---

## Cryogenic Transmission Lines

Power must be transmitted from the mountain (where there's light and +400°C) down into the crater (where the factory is at -150°C).

- Cable is laid along the shadowed slope
- At -150°C, aluminum resistance drops ~10x (cryoresistivity effect)
- Transmission losses: 3-5% instead of 15-20% at room temperature
- Can use smaller cross-section cables for the same capacity

**Note:** Aluminum is not a superconductor at any temperature. But Mercury's cryogenic temperatures (~120 K in shadow) reduce ohmic resistance enough for efficient power transmission over 1-2 km distances.

---

## Solar Panel Production

*Energy independence. Local photovoltaic manufacturing.*

The first factory uses GaAs cells from Earth. But scaling requires **local production** of silicon panels.

### Why Silicon, Not GaAs

| Parameter | GaAs | Silicon |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Efficiency | 30-40% | 18-22% |
| Raw materials | Gallium + Arsenic (scarce) | **20% of Mercury's crust** |
| Production | Epitaxy, clean rooms | Simpler, 90s technology |
| Verdict | First factory | **Scaling** |

### Power Consumption per Complex

| Consumer | Power | Notes |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Mass Driver (average) | 33 MW | 600 launches/day × 4.8 GJ |
| Solar furnaces (smelting) | 10 MW | Concentrators |
| Mirror production | 5 MW | Rolling, welding, packaging |
| Robots (~50 units × 5 kW) | 0.3 MW | Battery-powered |
| Control systems and communications | 2 MW | IT infrastructure |
| **TOTAL** | **~50 MW** | Rounded to 55 MW with margin |

**Note:** Calculation per [Mass Driver Scaling](production/railguns/scaling.qmd#energy-balance). The 55 MW value includes 10% margin for peak loads and losses.

### Silicon Panel Parameters

| Parameter | Value |
| :--- | :--- |
| Solar flux on Mercury | 10 kW/m² (orbital average) |
| Silicon cell efficiency | 18% |
| Output per 1 m² | 10 × 0.18 = **1.8 kW/m²** |
| Area per complex (55 MW) | **35,000 m²** (187×187 m square) |

### Aluminothermic Silicon Reduction

**Problem:** The traditional method (SiO₂ + C → Si + CO₂) requires carbon, which Mercury lacks.

**Solution:** Aluminothermy — reduction with aluminum.

```
3SiO₂ + 4Al → 3Si + 2Al₂O₃
```

| Advantage | Description |
| :--- | :--- |
| Local aluminum | From MRE electrolysis slag |
| No carbon import | Complete autonomy |
| Byproduct | Al₂O₃ (corundum) → ceramics, abrasives |

**Stoichiometry:**
- Per 1 kg silicon: 1.3 kg aluminum
- Byproduct: 1.3 kg corundum (Al₂O₃)

### Production Chain

| Stage | Process | Materials | Notes |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| 1 | Quartz sand (SiO₂) | Local | 20% of Mercury's crust |
| 2 | Aluminum | MRE slag | Already produced |
| 3 | **Aluminothermy** | Local | Solar furnace, 2000°C |
| 4 | Zone refining | — | Purification to solar grade |
| 5 | Czochralski method | Quartz crucible | Ingot ∅150 mm |
| 6 | Wire sawing | Diamond wire (Earth) | 200 µm wafers |
| 7 | P/B diffusion | Phosphorus + Boron (Earth) | p-n junction |
| 8 | Screen printing | Local aluminum | Contacts |
| 9 | SiNx deposition | Nitrogen (Earth) + Silane | Anti-reflection |
| 10 | Module assembly | Local aluminum | No glass needed (vacuum) |

**3 trips with GaAs panels — energy independence from day one:**

| Parameter | Value | Notes |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Complex consumption | 55 MW | Factory + MD + robots |
| GaAs panels (trip 1) | 35,000 m² = 56 MW | 1.75 t |

**Benefits of 3 trips:**
- Bootstrap without waiting for Swarm energy

# Section 2: Energy for Mass Drivers

*Pulsed power systems. High peak loads during mirror launches.*

## Mass Driver Power Consumption

### Per Single Launch

To launch a 116 kg mirror at 5 km/s requires:

```
Kinetic energy: 1.45 GJ
With 40% efficiency: 3.6 GJ
With system losses: ~4.8 GJ per launch
```

### Average Power (1 Mass Driver)

```
600 launches/day × 4.8 GJ = 2880 GJ/day
= 120 GJ/hour
= 33 MW (average power)
```

### Peak Power

```
During acceleration (10 sec): 400 MW
Between launches: charging capacitors
```

**Conclusion:** One Mass Driver consumes ~33 MW continuously. This is equivalent to **~2-3 mirrors** (through 18% PV efficiency).

---

## Capacitor Banks

**Problem:** Peak power of 400 MW for 10 seconds is impossible directly from solar panels.

**Solution:** Capacitors store energy between launches (2-3 minutes) and release it in pulses.

| Parameter | Value |
| :--- | :--- |
| Energy per launch | 4.8 GJ |
| Acceleration time | 10 sec |
| Peak power | 400 MW |
| Charging time | 2-3 minutes between launches |
| Average charging power | 33 MW |

**Operating principle:**
1. Solar panels continuously charge capacitors (33 MW)
2. 2-3 minutes pass between launches — enough to accumulate 4.8 GJ
3. At launch, capacitors instantly deliver 400 MW to MD coils
4. Cycle repeats 600 times per day

**Capacitor materials:**
- Dielectric: local silicates + ceramics
- Plates: aluminum (local)
- Bank mass: ~20 tons per MD

---

## Power Distribution Across Coils

The Mass Driver has several hundred coils along the 3-kilometer track. Energy is distributed sequentially:

| Section | Length | Coils | Power |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Acceleration (start) | 0-1 km | ~100 | 150 MW |
| Acceleration (middle) | 1-2 km | ~100 | 150 MW |
| Final acceleration | 2-3 km | ~100 | 100 MW |

**Control:** Coils activate sequentially as the projectile passes, creating a "traveling magnetic field."

---

## MD Cooling Systems (~20 MW heat)

### Heat Dissipation Problem

| Parameter | Value |
| :--- | :--- |
| Energy per launch | 4.8 GJ |
| Efficiency | 40% |
| Heat per shot | **2.9 GJ = 290 MW for 10 sec** |
| Interval between shots | 2–3 minutes |
| Continuous heat dissipation | **~20 MW** (at 600 shots/day) |

**Overheating consequences:**
- Coil overheating → efficiency drop → even more heat
- Thermal expansion of rails → projectile jamming
- Winding insulation degradation

### Solution: NaK Cooling + Radiators

**Cooling system:**

| Component | Description |
| :--- | :--- |
| Coolant | Eutectic NaK alloy (sodium-potassium) |
| Melting point | −12°C (liquid under all Mercury conditions) |
| Circulation | Pumps inside each coil |
| Radiators | Directed toward Mercury's shadow side (−180°C) |
| Radiator area | ~5000 m² per MD |

**Operating principle:**
1. NaK circulates through coils, absorbing heat
2. Hot NaK (~200°C) flows to radiators
3. Radiators radiate heat into cold space
4. Cooled NaK (~50°C) returns to coils

**Cryogenic temperature advantage:**
- Mercury's shadow side: −180°C
- Temperature difference ΔT = 200 − (−180) = 380°C
- High radiative cooling efficiency

### Cryo-Aluminum

**Problem:** Mercury has no copper, and aluminum at room temperature has 1.6× worse conductivity.

**Solution:** Use cryogenic cooling to increase aluminum conductivity.

| Material | At +20°C | At −180°C |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Copper | 100% | 400% |
| Aluminum | 60% | 360% |

**Conclusions:**
- At −180°C, aluminum nearly matches copper in conductivity
- Mass Driver efficiency is restored from 30% to **35-40%**
- Cooling solves two problems simultaneously: heat removal + efficiency increase
